title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: A mammoth boomerang returns new clues about early human toolmaking
items.description: New dates for a throwing weapon found in Poland reveal it as one of the earliest of its kind

items.title: Prestigious NSF graduate fellowship tilts toward AI and quantum
items.description: Students in the life sciences are shut out of latest cohort of 500 fellows

items.title: National rare disease effort among those upended by Trump’s freeze on Harvard grants
items.description: White House battle with Ivy League school disrupts databases and networks relied on by other universities

items.title: Following court order, NIH ceases new terminations of politically sensitive grants
items.description: After a judge told agency to restore hundreds of killed grants, NIH backs off plans to cancel more existing projects

items.title: Tumors may get supercharged by acquiring powerhouses of nerve cells
items.description: Scientists spot mitochondria traveling through “bridges” into nearby cancer cells

items.title: Space telescope spies smallest alien world to be seen directly
items.description: NASA’s JWST observatory takes picture of young, Saturn-size world that grew by sweeping up debris

items.title: Africa’s embattled giraffe populations growing after years of decline
items.description: Still, several populations should be considered “endangered,” new report finds

items.title: DeepMind’s latest AI tool makes sense of changes in the human genome
items.description: By predicting the effects of genetic variants, AlphaGenome could boost synthetic biology and the search for cancer genes

items.title: These squirrels’ scaly tails help them climb slippery trees
items.description: The grippy appendages may help engineers design robots that can navigate dense forests

items.title: How fast were dinosaurs? These mud-covered birds may show us
items.description: Researchers used live birds to test a 50-year-old way of estimating dino speeds from fossil footprints
